math_problem: Each of four doors is randomly either open or closed. What is the probability that exactly two of the four doors are open? Instead of determining the probability of exactly two open doors among the four, simply find $Pr$, where $Pr$ is the probability that exactly two of the four doors are open derived from counting the favorable configurations among all possible states of the doors. The line with equation $y=2x-(Pr + 45/8)$ is translated upwards by 4 units. What is the $x$-intercept of the resulting line?

A2997: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Combinations
